awd_titl_txt: Multi-frequency Oscillations: Regularity, Irregularity, and Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on  multi-frequency phenomena arising in biological, electrical and mechanical  oscillatory systems with or without damping. It consists of two separate but closely related parts: 1. Quasi-periodic and weakly quasi-periodic motions; 2. Biological oscillations and complexities.  Part 1 of the project aims at the  study  of the existence, stability, and mechanism for both regular and irregular multifrequency oscillations in properly degenerate Hamiltonian systems, Poisson-Hamilton systems, and Hamiltonian networks. Part 2 of the project is devoted to the study of biological oscillations and complexity  in bio-chemical reaction systems and bio-networks, in both deterministic and stochastic settings, with respect to issues such as stransient oscillations, stochastic oscillations, stability  of invariant measures, and  the connections among degeneracy, robustness, and system complexity.

The project focuses on  multi-frequency phenomena in nature especially those arising in  biological, electrical, and mechanical  systems. It is predicted by many experiments and computer simulations that physical systems involving multi-frequency can produce many complex dynamical outcomes oscillating in multiple phases. But the mechanism of such complexity is far from well-understood, especially when ambient noise is present. In the  project, the PI plans to develop a mathematical theory towards a fundamental understanding of such complexity.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed at making some fundamental understanding of
complex dynamical phenomena in dynamical systems caused by the
interaction of frequencies and the influence of noises. Some
mathematical theory is developed toward making a fundamental
understanding of such complexity and various applications to
problems arising in  biological, electrical, and mechanical systems
are considered. During the support period of this grant, the PI has
written a total of 16 research articles in related subjects with 11
published or to be published in professional journals.

The PI made a large effort in education and career training at
all levels. During the support period, the PI  supervised
research projects for 4 postdocs, 5 Ph.D students, 2 senior
undergraduate students. He was a member of thesis committees for 11
Ph.D theses and 10 M.S. theses, and he served as the chief adviser
for a honors class consisting of about 20 students in mathematics
and physics. He taught 2 mini-courses to graduate students at
international conferences and delivered two frontier lectures at
summer schools and training camps. He was a main organizer of 13
international conferences/schools which have attracted a significant
number of students participants.

During the support period, the PI delivered over 30 invited
lectures at international conferences on subjects related to the NSF
supported work. He served as a main editor for 7 professional
journals.


Last Modified: 07/05/2015
Modified by: Yingfei Yi
